Rationale

The  Project  is  designed  to  improve  the  urban  environment  in
Vientiane  and  reinforce  the  Government's  reforms  for  effective
and  responsive  urban  management. 
It  combines  physical
infrastructure  and  service  improvements  with  interventions  for
decentralized urban governance and extensive capacity building
for  the  Vientiane  Urban  Development  Administration  Authority
(VUDAA).  Physical  investments  consist  of  improvements  to
drainage,  roads,  traffic  management  and  safety,  solid  waste
management,  and  sanitation.  The  Project  incorporates  a  social
strategy to ensure active participation of the urban communities
in project implementation and effective targeting of the poor and
vulnerable.  The  project  area  covers  a  hundred  urban  villages
with  about  162,000  residents  within  Vientiane  and  falls  under
the jurisdiction of VUDAA.

BACKGROUND

With  a  per  capita  income  of  about  $300,  the  Lao  PDR  is  one  of  the  least  developed
3.
countries  in  Asia.  Poverty  incidence  is  estimated  at  38.6  percent.  The  United  Nations  human
development index places the country in the bottom fifth of the world's nations. The country is
essentially rural, but since the mid-1980s the expanded marketing and commercial opportunities
following economic liberalization stimulated urban growth. As a result, growing numbers of rural
people  were  drawn  to  the  urban  areas  in  search  of  better  livelihoods.  The  present  urban
population of 0.85 million, which represents 17 percent of the total, is estimated to increase by
more  than  50  percent  over  the  next  10  years.  Although  the  economy  is  largely  rural,  with
agriculture  accounting  for  some  50  percent  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP),  the  role  of  the
urban sector is growing. During 1996-1998 the industry and services sector components of GDP
increased  at  average  annual  rates  of  11.5  and  7.2  percent,  respectively,  compared  with  4.3
percent for agriculture, implying the productivity and associated opportunities in urban areas.

1.

Urban Environment and Infrastructure and Services

5.
While  infrastructure  and  services  in  Vientiane  have  improved  significantly  over  the  last
five years with major investments in primary roads and drainage funded by ADB,5 other funding
agencies, and the Government, a focus on primary infrastructure constrained the ability of the
newly  constructed  infrastructure  to  realize  its  full  potential  benefits.  There  remains  a  need  for
further  development  to  (i)  maximize  the  utility  of  the  existing  primary  networks  and  allow  a
greater  share  of  population,  especially  the  poor,  to  benefit  from  environmental  improvements;
and (ii) control future environmental degradation. Storm-water drainage is the key infrastructure
development  issue.  Flooding  continues  to  occur  away  from  the  main  drainage  network
developed with recent investments, and stagnant polluted wastewater still lies in open roadside
channels  because  the  primary  network  is  incomplete  and  the  secondary  and  tertiary  networks
are largely unimproved. There are almost 300 kilometers (km) of drainage channels within the
urban area, of which about 162 km are either in poor or very poor condition. Moreover, lack of
routine  cleaning,  maintenance,  and  rehabilitation  constrains  the  proper  functioning  of  the
existing systems.

6.
The  impact  of  poor  sanitation  on  the  city  as  a  whole  is  significant  in  terms  of  potential
health risks. There is no sewerage system, and sanitation is primarily through on-site facilities. A
septage disposal and treatment facility was constructed and maintenance systems initiated with
ADB  assistance.  While  74  percent  of  the  urban  households  have  access  to  on-site  sanitation
facilities,  these  facilities  are  generally  poorly  designed  and  constructed,  and  perform
inadequately.  Moreover,  the  prevailing  methods  and  frequency  for  treatment  and  disposal  of
wastewater are inadequate. A flat terrain, high water table, and low soil permeability exacerbate
the  problems  with  the  present  system  of  on-site  sanitation,  resulting  in  failure  of  the  systems,
overflow of effluent, and pollution of surface waters and drains. It is common practice to dispose
of  sullage  in  surface  drains  and  drainage  channels.  The  storm-water  drainage  system  is
generally  contaminated  by  wastewater  that  ends  up  in  wetlands  and  marshes,  contributing
further  to  environmental  degradation.  Lack  of  an  effective  system  for  maintenance  and
enforcement of sanitation regulations compounds these problems.

8.
Of the approximately 300 km of roads within the Vientiane urban area, only one third are
paved.  The  remaining  roads,  which  are  mainly  earth  or  gravel,  are  in  poor  condition.
Consequently,  large  volumes  of  mud  are  carried  by  vehicles  onto  newly  constructed  primary
roads  especially  during  the  monsoon  period.  This  compounds  inadequate  maintenance  and
accelerates deterioration of the roads. The growing use of motorized vehicles on unpaved roads
contributes  to  respiratory  problems  caused  by  suspended  particulate  matter.  Tertiary  roads,
which  account  for  almost  half  of  the  road  network,  are  usually  impassable  to  vehicles  after
heavy  rainfall.  Very  few  roads  are  adequately  lit,  contributing  to  traffic  accidents  and  personal
insecurity at night. The standards for road discipline and traffic management are poor. There is
a high incidence of traffic accidents with road casualties at alarming levels. During 1995-1999,
fatalities per year averaged 12.5 per 10,000 registered vehicles, which is markedly higher than
the figures for other countries in the region.

2.

Urban Poverty

9.
A  participatory  poverty  assessment,  conducted  under  the  TA  for  preparing  the  Project,
suggests that 18 percent of the city's households can be classified as poor6, including 3 percent
who  belong  to  the  poorest  groups  where  individual  cash  income  may  be  only  $8  per  month.
Unlike other cities in the region, where the poor reside in well-defined slum areas, the poor in
Vientiane  are  distributed  throughout  the  city  in  heterogeneous  urban  communities  where  they
often live adjacent to properties of higher income families. There is considerable diversity in the
conditions  and  requirements  of  the  poor,  and  a  gradation  of  services  and  infrastructure  is
required to meet the specific needs of and levels of affordability to various groups of the poor.
The vast majority of the poor live in low-lying wetland areas, which are flooded for most of the
year, and where water can reach depths of over a meter during the wet season. These areas
are  acutely  underserviced,  links  from  dwellings  to  access  roads  are  via  difficult  routes,  and  in
most  cases,  are  via  narrow  timber  planks  balanced  above  contaminated  floodwater.  The  poor
do  not  have  access  to  a  typical  range  of  sanitation  options.  Conditions  are  unhygienic,  water-
and  feces-borne  diseases  are  highly  prevalent,  and  many  elderly  people  are  trapped  in  their
houses  during  rainy  season.  Flooding  also  hinders  subsistence  economic  activities  such  as
growing  vegetables  and  raising  small  livestock,  risking  the  food  security  of  the  poor.  There  is
virtually  no  practice  of  household  or  community  management  of  solid  waste.  The  participatory
poverty  assessment  reveals  that  the  problems  most  frequently  identified  by  the  poor  are
drainage, poor access roads, uncollected rubbish, and sanitation.

Built-Up Environment

12.
The  Vientiane  urban  area  is  growing  in  an  unplanned  manner.  While  the  city  has  a
master  plan,  a  zoning  system,  and  development  control  procedures,  supported  by  a  Planning
Law, the system in its current form and operation has limited impact on urban development, and
has  failed  to  guide  growth.  The  master  plan,  approved  in  1992  and  revised  recently,  cannot
manage contemporary urban growth in the absence of a program approach and local area plans
that provide a clear basis for building control. There is no policy at present for a number of large
open spaces that have the potential to develop in a haphazard manner. The master plan does
not include a strategy to protect the unique cultural heritage in the central part of Vientiane that
is  threatened  by  uncontrolled  development.  In  addition,  the  revised  master  plan  allows
conversion  of  a  number  of  wetlands,  which  function  as  natural  flood  retention  basins,  to
residential  use.  There  is  an  urgent  need  for  a  program  of  plans  to  address  these  issues  and
ensure that development in Vientiane is environmentally and culturally sustainable and that the
remaining vacant land in the city's urban fabric is used appropriately and efficiently.

13.
Further,  the  master  plan,  prepared  under  the  centralized  planning  system,  prevailing
until recently, lacks ownership by the urban stakeholders, including VUDAA that is responsible

2.

Urban Governance and Finance in Transition

Urban  governance  in  the  Lao  PDR  has  undergone  a  major  transition  over  the  last  five
17.
years.  Until  recently  the  country  did  not  have  a  distinct  and  decentralized  system  of  urban
administration.  The  Ministry  of  Communication,  Transport,  Posts,  and  Construction  (MCTPC),
through  its  provincial  and  prefectural  departments,  was  responsible  for  urban  planning  and
management along with its responsibility for rural areas. Public sector investment in urban areas
was  financed  entirely  through  the  annual  budget  allocations  from  national  to  provincial
governments,  without  considering  local  plans  and  budget  requirements.  No  specific  budget
heading was made for urban infrastructure maintenance. In 1995, the Government launched a
program  of  decentralization  and  created  the  Vientiane  Urban  Development  and  Management
Committee  (VUDMC)  as  a  legal  urban  entity.  A  decentralized  form  of  urban  governance  was
advanced  with  the  consolidation  of  VUDMC  as  VUDAA  in  1999.  VUDAA  was  envisioned  to
eventually  become  an  autonomous  urban  local  government  with  (i)  responsibilities  and
commensurate  capacities  for  planning  and  managing  infrastructure  and  services  within  the
Vientiane urban area, and (ii) its own sources of revenue and budget to meet its expenditures
for  the  delegated  tasks.  The  creation  of  a  distinct  and  decentralized  urban  entity  in  Vientiane
was followed by the establishment in 1997 of urban development and administration authorities
(UDAAs) in four major secondary towns.

18.
The Government's commitment to decentralization has become the dominant theme of a
number  of  prime  ministerial  (PM)  decrees,  instructions,  decisions,  notifications,  and  policy
statements. Most significant in the decentralization process are decrees 177/PM issued in 1997
and  14/PM  in  1999,  and  the  operational  instructions  of  141/PM  issued  in  May  2000  for
implementing  decrees  177/PM  and  14/PM.  These  decrees  recognize  UDAAs  in  Vientiane  and
secondary towns as legal entities exclusively responsible for urban communities, and define the
position of UDAAs as organizations within provincial and prefectural administrative apparatuses.
UDAAs  are  delegated  tasks  to  plan,  implement,  manage,  and  control  urban  development
activities, including roads, drainage, collection and disposal of waste, sanitation and protection
of environment, public lighting, preventing riverbank erosion, and maintaining public parks. The

 6

delegated  tasks  include  land  use  planning  and  building  control  in  cooperation  with  other
agencies.  More  importantly,  the  decrees  empower  UDAAs  to  raise  revenues  within  the  levels
set  by  the  central  Government,  from  a  range  of  sources  including  service  fees  and  charges,
income from movable or immovable property, sharing of national taxes, borrowing loans, local
and foreign grants, and allocations of funds from the central Government. UDAAs are entrusted
with  using  these  funds  to  perform  the  delegated  tasks.  Finally,  the  decrees  also  provide
guidelines on the organizational structure and working procedures of UDAAs.

19. Within the framework of the foregoing decrees, VUDAA has been gradually developing
itself  as  an  urban  entity.  It  has  made  some  progress  in  developing  its  organizational  structure
and  capacity  to  prepare  for  its  new  responsibilities.  The  president  or  mayor  of  the  VUDAA  is
vice governor of the Vientiane Prefecture, and VUDAA is managed by a board chaired by the
president and comprising the heads of the four districts in the Vientiane urban area. VUDAA has
a  manager  who  is  the  most  senior  staff  member  in  the  organization.  The  manager  acts  as
secretary  to  the  VUDAA  board.  There  are  two  deputy  managers  responsible  for  technical  and
administrative matters, respectively. Under this management structure, VUDAA has at present
five  major  divisions.  It  has  about  70  technical  and  administrative  staff,  and  about  160  field
workers. The number of staff recruited over the last quarter of 2000, has significantly increased.
Staff  have  been  transferred  from  other  departments  of  the  Vientiane  Prefecture,  and  recruited
from outside. More importantly, the governor of Vientiane issued, in December 2000, Decision
1804 that allowed VUDAA to levy and collect a range of specific direct and indirect user charges
and fees, including charges for solid waste collection, desludging services, and fees for vehicle
parking,  building  permits,  advertising  signs,  leasing  public  land,  urban  obligation  fees  from  all
buildings  and  commercial  outlets,  and  surcharges  for  water,  electricity,  and  fuel  consumption.
The  governor's  decision  was  confirmed  by  a  PM  decision,  21/PM,  on  26  April  2001  to  ensure
that  the  income,  to  be  generated  through  water  and  electricity  surcharges,  will  be  made
available  to  VUDAA.  These  initiatives  in  the  urban  sector  are  also  supportive  of  the  national
goals  of  the  Government  for  domestic  resource  mobilization  to  finance  recurrent  expenditures
for social development and to sustain existing physical assets.

20.
However,  in  moving  from  a  centralized  form  of  urban  governance  to  a  decentralized
mode,  the  Government  faces  a  number  of  further  challenges.  The  Lao  PDR's  existing
Constitution does not provide for a distinct urban territorial authority. In addition, the provisions
of  the  prevailing  State  Budget  Law,  which  stipulates  a  centralized  financial  system,  are  not
compatible  with  the  Government's  policy  of  decentralized  revenue  generation  and  financial
management reflected in the foregoing decrees. Apart from inconsistency in the legal basis, the
current position of the UDAAs in the national territorial hierarchy is ambiguous. The position of
UDAAs as administrative units of provincial and prefectural governments does not fully conform
to the concept of autonomous urban local governments. In addition, the interface and linkages
of UDAAs with other tiers of administration and with district authorities are not clearly defined,
especially  in  the  case  of  VUDAA  whose  geographic  jurisdiction  cuts  across  four  districts.  The
PM's instruction 01/PM, issued in March 2000, which stipulates decentralization from central to
lower  levels  of  Governments  and  defines  the  province  as  the  strategic  unit,  the  district  as  the
budget  and  planning  unit,  and  the  village  as  implementing  unit,  makes  no  reference  to  urban
authorities. There is also the issue of the geographic jurisdiction of the authority of VUDAA. The
Vientiane  urban  area,  for  which  VUDAA  is  responsible,  was  determined  in  1995.  The  existing
boundary of the Vientiane urban area does not cover the urban area, recently developed on the
outskirts  of  the  city,  and  is  leading  to    inconsistencies  in  the  approach  to  and  the  levels  of
services.

21. While  VUDAA  derives  power  from  the  foregoing  decrees  to  raise  revenues  and  utilize
them for the urban tasks, as a department of the Vientiane Prefecture VUDAA needs to obtain

 7

approval from the central Government when setting charges, from the Governor for its annual
budget, and from the Vientiane Prefecture administration for expenses above an agreed upon
threshold,  resulting  in  incomplete  financial  autonomy  for  VUDAA.  A  great  deal  of  effort  is
associated  with  setting  up  the  cost  recovery  measures  within  VUDAA,  and  there  is  broad
consensus  in  the  Government  on  their  implementation.  However,  some  issues  are  associated
with the recently adopted cost recovery measures. The structure of charges and fees does not
fully  reflect  the  principles  of  equity  and  consumption  levels  of  services.  Following  the
Government's  decentralization  process,  responsibility  for  collecting  some  national  taxes  has
been devolved to the village authorities. While village-level collection of revenue is likely to lead
to  greater  transparency,  a  framework  has  yet  to  be  established  to  ensure  transparency  and
increased collection efficiency.

22.
The overall capacity of VUDAA to effectively perform its new functions and to exercise
its power to generate revenue and manage its financial resources needs further strengthening.
Management  and  operational  systems  are  in  the  process  of  being  established.  The  staff
recently increased, but in many cases new members lack experience and skills appropriate to
their  respective  positions.  There  is  need  to  further  develop  management  systems  and  human
resources to enable VUDAA to perform its delegated tasks better. The scale of reforms toward
an entirely distinct system of decentralized urban governance in the Lao PDR in general, and in
Vientiane  in  particular,  necessitates  extensive  and  long-term  support  for  the  reforms  and
associated capacity building for VUDAA.

4.

Good Governance

34.
Establishment  of  VUDAA  and  UDAAs,  whereby  the  urban  administration  is  brought
closer to the people, is a major step to good governance. Recent experience with UDAAs has
clearly  shown  increased  interaction  between  the  urban  community  and  the  Government.
However,  further  reforms  are  required  to  harness  the  full  potential  of  decentralized  urban
governance  to  promote  good  governance  reflected  as  participatory  management,  downward
accountability, and transparency in urban affairs. The recent policy of the Government to assign
to the villages a greater role in development provides an immense scope to promote responsive
governance  in  managing  urban  areas.  The  Project  will  support  the  establishment  and
institutionalization of mechanisms for enhanced two-way communication between VUDAA and
the  villages.  The  Project  approaches,  which  reinforce  the  roles  of  village  organizations  and
communities, will catalyze reforms for responsive urban governance. The capacities of VUDAA,
village organizations, and communities in participatory urban management will be strengthened.

5.

Effective Planning

35.
Both ADB and the Government have recognized the importance of urban planning as a
basic  requirement  of  a  cost-effective  infrastructure  development,  environmental  and  cultural
sustainability, and equitable spatial organization of the city in which all income groups including
the poor can find living space of reasonable quality. ADB since 1995 provided assistance in the
preparation  and  approval  of  the  master  plan  for  Vientiane.  There  is  need  at  this  stage  to
improve the effectiveness of the existing planning system and the master plan. The Government
has  agreed  to  a  number  of  interventions.  The  master  plan  will  be  amended  to  ensure  the
protection of ecologically fragile areas. VUDAA will adopt a program approach with a number of
strategic  and  action  plans  for  priority  areas  to  prevent  unplanned  development  and  to  protect
the cultural heritage of Vientiane. Existing zoning regulations will be reviewed and simplified to
facilitate development control at VUDAA level. Innovative land development techniques will be
tested  to  establish  effective  instruments  for  planned  development.  The  Project  will  assist  the
Government and VUDAA in undertaking the reforms, and VUDAA's capacity will be enhanced to
enable it to perform planning and development control functions effectively.

6. 

Urban Poverty Reduction

36.
The  Government  is  committed  to  poverty  reduction  and  has  specific  targets  to  reduce
poverty  in  Vientiane.  The  Project,  whose  design  was  guided  by  a  participatory  poverty
assessment in Vientiane, has a strong focus on the needs of the poor, and incorporates a social
strategy to address poverty and associated social issues. ADB will pursue the development of
pro-poor  urban  management  skills  within  VUDAA  by  sensitizing  the  VUDAA  staff  to  urban
poverty,  and  strengthening  VUDAA's  and  villages'  capacity  in  participatory  local  planning  and
development. The poverty impact of the Project will be closely monitored. Coordination will also
be maintained with initiatives for poverty reduction at the Vientiane Prefecture level.

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A.

Rationale

38.
Current  deficiencies  in  basic  infrastructure  and  services  in  the  Vientiane  urban  area
inhibit economic growth and undermine the quality of life of the urban residents and especially
the  poor.  Despite  recent  investments  in  primary  road  and  drainage  networks,  the  poor
conditions of the secondary and tertiary infrastructure constrain the full potential of and benefits
from recent improvements in primary infrastructure and services. In the absence of a complete
storm water drainage system, flooding continues to be a perennial problem affecting large parts
of  the  urban  area.  Frequent  flooding  contributes  to  the  poor  state  of  roads.  Many  of  the
secondary  and  local  roads  remain  impassable  during  and  following  heavy  rainfall  thereby
disrupting the urban economy. The inadequate sanitation systems compound the environmental
problems.  Lack  of  basic  infrastructure  and  services  at  community  and  household  levels  has  a
particularly adverse impact on the lives of the poor who primarily live in low-lying marginal land
subject  to  flooding  for  most  of  the  year.  Inadequate  environmental  conditions  and  associated
poor  health  and  low  productivity  are  the  major  characteristics  of  poverty  in  Vientiane  and  the
most overwhelming problem faced by the poor.

39.
Sustained economic growth and the quality of life of the residents in the Vientiane urban
area  are  further  constrained  by  the  still  evolving  urban  institutional  framework  and  nascent
urban  management.  While  significant  progress  has  been  made  toward  decentralized  urban
governance,  whereby  the  diverse  needs  of  an  urban  economy  and  a  population  can  be
addressed  more  effectively,  the  tasks  ahead  to  make  VUDAA  a  fully  autonomous,  financially
sustainable, and organizationally competent urban authority are considerable.

40.
For  Vientiane  to  become  an  important  driver  of  the  national  economy  and  the  locus  of
urban  poverty  reduction,  it  is  essential  that  the  quality  of  the  urban  environment  be  improved.
Development  of  the  primary  infrastructure  of  Vientiane  has  progressed  well,  but  is  still
incomplete,  and  there  is  need  at  this  stage  to  shift  the  focus  of  efforts  to  secondary  and
community-level infrastructure and services to ensure that environmental improvements are felt
by  all,  especially  the  poor.  Equally  important  is  smooth  progress  in  decentralization  and
accomplishment  of  key  reforms  and  development  of  VUDAA  as  an  urban  entity  with  the
necessary operational and management systems, staff, and financial resources. The extent of
reforms needed to fully achieve decentralized urban governance in the Lao PDR in general, and
in  Vientiane  in  particular,  require  extensive  and  long-term  support  for  reforms  and  the
corresponding capacity building.

B.

Objectives and Scope

41.
The  objectives  of  the  Project  are  to  improve  the  quality  of  life  of  the  urban  residents,
especially  the  poor  and  the  disadvantaged,  and  to  enhance  urban  productivity  and  economic
growth  in  the  Vientiane  urban  area.  To  this  end,  the  Project  has  two  specific  objectives:  (i)  to

secondary  and  tertiary-level  infrastructure  thus,  allowing  a  greater  share  of  the  population,

second  intervention  in  the  Vientiane  urban  area,  and  incorporates  lessons  learned  from  the

Citywide Infrastructure and Environmental Improvements (Part A)

43.

73.
Experience in private sector participation in urban service delivery in Vientiane has been
limited,  confined  to  the  desludging  of  septic  tanks  and  solid  waste  management.  While  there
appears  to  be  potential  for  private  sector  participation  in  various  stages  and  sets  of  urban
services (especially in O&M), a number of factors constrain outsourcing to the private sector in a
full  scale  in  the  near  future.  Experience  with  the  private  sector  involvement  in  the  solid  waste
management in Vientiane indicates that the level of fees and collection efficiency is insufficient
to allow local entrepreneurs to achieve a satisfactory level of cost-recovery. In addition, VUDAA
at  present  has  insufficient  technical  and  managerial  skills  to  undertake  and  supervise  service
delivery  by  private  contractors  on  a  large  scale.  Another  constraint  is  limited  private  sector
capacity.  Experience  with  private  sector  involvement  in  septic  tank  cleaning  reveals  the
detrimental effect of lack of a sound regulatory framework, with some private operators dumping
septage  improperly.  The  strategy  for  private  sector  participation  in  the  delivery  of  urban
services, therefore, requires a multipronged approach involving (i) a regulatory framework and

charges and fees at reasonable levels. It may be also necessary to assist the private sector in

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

The  proposed  Project  will  benefit  about  162,000  residents  of  the  Vientiane  urban  area
81.
through  improved  urban  environment  and  living  conditions  resulting  from  upgraded  roads  and
drainage,  improved  traffic  management  and  road  safety,  wider  coverage  of  solid  waste
collection,  and  improved  sanitation  conditions.  The  economy  will  benefit  from  increased  urban
efficiency as the project interventions will mitigate disruptions to urban economy caused by poor
road  and  traffic  conditions,  constant  flooding  and  damage  to  urban  assets,  and  inadequate
urban services. Urban poverty will be reduced by providing basic infrastructure and services for
the  poor  and  a  social  strategy  with  inclusive  processes  incorporated  into  the  Project.  The
Project will directly improve the living conditions of 81,000 urban residents through village area
improvements, a partially coincident 60,000 people through drainage improvements, and about
16,000  people  through  improved  solid  waste  collection  and  disposal.  The  general  population
and the economy will gain because the increased capacity of VUDAA will result in sustainable
improvements to the urban environment and effective delivery of services. The Project's support
for decentralized urban governance and participatory management and empowerment of village
communities  in  local  planning  and  service  delivery  will  lead  to  responsive  urban  governance
with a greater concern for the needs of the urban poor.

82.
More  specifically,  the  Project  will  contribute  to  (i)  reduced  damage,  disruption,  and
detrimental  health  impacts  from  localized  flooding;  (ii)  reduced  dust  from  traffic  on  local  roads
and lower vehicle operating costs on local, secondary, and primary roads; (iii) reduced deaths
and  injury  from  road  accidents;  (iv)  improved  environmental  and  health  outcomes  from  solid
waste  collection  and  disposal,  and  sanitation  improvements;  (v)  increased  community
awareness  of  environmental  health,  and  enhanced  village  capacities  in  local  planning,
implementation and O&M of local infrastructure, with focus on the urban poor; and (vi) improved
planning,  development  control,  environmental  and  cultural  sustainability,  and  sustainable
service delivery through enhanced capacity of VUDAA in urban management and local resource
mobilization.

83.

range from 12.4 to 41.4 percent, with the lowest EIRR occurring for a subproject to construct a
new section of road for which the benefits to the network as a whole are not fully reflected in the
evaluation. The roads component is robust, and will remain viable even with a 105 percent rise
in costs or a 51 percent decline in benefits.

The  overall  EIRR  for  the  storm  water  drainage  component  is  11.9  percent  based  on

savings in damage to private buildings and property. Additional unquantified benefits include (i)

2.

Cost Recovery, Subsidies, and Sustainability

95.
A  national  expenditure  and  consumption  survey  in  1997  and  early  1998  indicated  that
16.7  percent  of  the  urban  population  in  Vientiane  is  below  the  poverty  line,  based  on  the
equivalent  income  needed  to  purchase  2,100  calories  per  person  per  day  plus  some
expenditure for nonfood items. Expressing this amount in current prices is susceptible to error,
given  the  rapid  subsequent  inflation,  e.g.,  142  percent  in  1998  and  108  percent  in  1999.  The
present  poverty  line  is  estimated  to  be  between  about  KN150,000-190,000  per  household  per

average monthly household income about KN730,000 ($89). Households at the lower end of the

surcharges  on  water  and  electricity,  higher  fees  for  solid  waste  collection  and  disposal,  and  a

Environment and Social Dimensions

100.
The initial environmental examination indicates that the impacts of the Project will (i) not
involve the accelerated use of scarce resources and will in the long term contribute to their more
efficient use by improving the efficiency of the urban system, (ii) have a neutral impact on the
ecology of the impact area, (iii) have a significantly positive impact on the physical environment,

population through enhancement of the physical environment. Negative environmental impacts

cost of the Project. The long-term environmental benefits of the Project depend on proper O&M
of  the  completed  investments.  Therefore,  the  Project  has  provided  for  the  purchase  of  basic
maintenance  equipment,  measures  for  community  involvement,  and  building  the  capacity  of

101.
The  Project  will  improve  the  living  conditions  of  the  urban  residents,  the  local
environment, and the infrastructure and services needed by households and businesses in the
Vientiane  urban  area.  Beneficiaries  include  (i)  direct  beneficiaries  of  improvements,  including
people who (a) use new and upgraded infrastructure and services such as improved roads and
solid  waste  services;  (b)  benefit  from  the  improved  infrastructure  and  services  that  result  in
reduced  flooding,  less  dust  from  unsealed  roads,  and  the  avoided  cost  and  trauma  of  traffic
accidents;  and  (c)  benefit  from  empowerment  and  involvement  through  the  community
preparation  and  awareness  program;  and  (ii)  indirect  beneficiaries  who  gain  from  (a)  an
improved quality of life resulting from the improved urban environment, (b) the economic growth
that  will  be  fostered  by  improvements  in  infrastructure  and  services,  and  (c)  sustained  and
equitable  improvements  to  the  urban  living  conditions  resulting  from  project  interventions  for
effective  and  responsive  urban  governance.  The  involvement  of  the  communities  in  project
implementation  will  complement  and  reinforce  the  immediate  economic  and  health  benefits
associated  with  the  local  road,  drainage,  sanitation,  solid  waste  management,  and  traffic
management components by ensuring sustainability and a sense of ownership.

102. About 18 percent of the population of the Vientiane urban area, or 30,000 people can be
defined  as  very  poor  on  the  basis  of  their  limited  income.  These  people  incur  a  multiplicity  of
problems  such  as  inability  to  afford  three  meals  per  day,  limited  intake  of  protein,  children
generally  leaving  school  after  reaching  12  years  of  age,  and  most  importantly,  the
consequences of living in low-lying areas that are acutely underserved, and subject to flooding
and  consequent  environmental  and  health  problems.  The  VAI  component  will  directly  benefit
approximately  15,000  poor  people  while  30,000  poor  will  benefit  indirectly  from  citywide
improvements. The Project will provide a range of infrastructure and services (i) that the poor,
through a participatory poverty assessment, unanimously indicated as the highest priorities; in
particular  poor  drainage  and  access  that  has  imposed  limitations  on  their  livelihoods,  health,
and  the  quality  of  life,  (ii)  that  will  improve  inadequate  solid  waste  collection  systems  and
sanitation  that  are  grossly  inadequate  in  areas  where  the  poor  live,  and  (iii)  that  will  offer  a
range  of  service  levels  affordable  to  various  low-income  groups.  The  community  preparation
and awareness program under VAI will maximize the benefits from physical improvements by (i)
furthering  the  concern  of  community  leaders  for  the  needs  of  the  poor  and  improving  their

C. 

Project Risks

104. Potential risks associated with the Project include (i) legal inconsistencies relating to the
structure of urban governance and a level of uncertainty resulting from the use of decrees as a
means for implementing reforms in the urban sector, (ii) inadequate rates for user charges and
fees and poor cost recovery and limited capacity of VUDAA to undertake its assigned functions

fees and charges and perceived low willingness of community to pay for urban services, and (iv)
inadequate experience and capacity of VUDAA and village communities in participatory project
planning and implementation.

To mitigate these risks, the Project has devised a strategy, reflected in the urban policy

and  institutional  reform  agenda  and  the  corresponding  project  assistance  under  the  capacity

constitute  an  important  element  of  the  reform  agenda  and  the  focus  of  project  assistance
through the capacity building component. The risk relating to the limited experience of VUDAA

community  preparation  and  awareness  program  that  seeks  building  the  capacities  of  the
communities  and  VUDAA  in  community-based  decision  making  and  implementation  of  urban
infrastructure  and  services.  The  issue  of  the  perceived  low  willingness  to  pay  for  the  services

community  understanding  of  the  cost  implications  of  the  services  and  the  consequent  public
support for user charges and fees.

B.

Program Approach

3.
VAI adopts a demand-led, sector program approach, taking the village as the unit for the
community/tertiary-level  infrastructure  improvements.  The  VAI  process  incorporates  (i)  a  high
level of community involvement in decision making, and (ii) a community contribution to ensure
that  improvements  match  community  requirements  and  benefit  from  community  commitment.
Starting with two pilot villages, the program will be built up to cover up to 12 new villages a year.
Three  additional  villages  are  anticipated  to  be  admitted  to  form  the  first  year’s  program;
thereafter,  villages  will  compete  for  places  in  each  subsequent  year’s  annual  program.  Most
villages are expected to apply for inclusion, and about 50 of VUDAA’s 100 villages are likely to
benefit from the program.

C.

General Principles

4.
Although  VAI  adopts  a  demand-led  approach,  the  villages  applying  for  inclusion  in  the
VAI program will have to accept and adhere to three general guiding principles: (i) community
participation  and  joint  decision  making,  especially  by  the  poor  and  women,  in  planning,
component  selection,  implementation  arrangements,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation;  (ii)
transparency and accountability; and (iii) commitment to cost sharing and participation in O&M.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT ACTION PLAN

A. 

Introduction

1.
The  Project  involves  the  improvement  or  construction  of  about  36  kilometers  (km)  of
major  roads,  14  km  of  main  drainage,  and  a  variety  of  other  tertiary-level  infrastructure  and
service improvements. Most of the proposed improvements will be made within existing rights-
of-way, and as such no additional land is required. In some cases, however, the proposed new
alignments  or  right-of-way  widening  will  involve  the  acquisition  of  land  and  also  affect  a  few
structures. A full resettlement action plan, which is a supplementary appendix, was prepared on
the  basis  of  comprehensive  socioeconomic  and  physical  surveys,  and  interviews  with  the
concerned households.

B. 

Scope and Scale of Resettlement

2.
Resettlement  and  relocation  activities  will  be  limited  since  (i)  most  subproject
components  involve  work  within  existing  rights-of-way,  (ii)  the  amount  of  new  land  required  is
very small, and (iii) most of this is at the edge of the urban area. The Project will require 12.9
hectares (ha). About 9 ha is in private use whereas the remaining 3.9 ha is government-owned
land. Of the over 30,000 households within the Vientiane urban area, only about 89 households
(500  persons)  will  be  affected  by  full  partial  loss  of  their  houses,  outbuildings,  property
boundaries, or paddy lands. No encroachers or squatters were found in the affected areas.

3.
Of  the  total  89  households  affected,  48  will  have  effects  on  their  houses  or  other
structures.  Eighteen  of  these  structures  are  temporary  shelters,  made  of  light  materials
(bamboo), and the remaining 30 are of brick or wood. Many affected structures are outhouses
rather  than  the  main  family  dwelling.  Where  the  dwelling  is  affected,  only  part  is  required.  In
most  cases,  householders  will  have  to  give  up  narrow  strips  of  unirrigated  paddy  land.  These
householders  will  be  provided  with  either  replacements  from  adjoining  land,  or  land  of  equal
utility and value elsewhere within the same district, or they will be paid the full market value of
the  land  taken.  Trees,  shrubs,  or  gardens  will  be  affected  in  a  few  households,  and  in  such
cases full compensation will be paid. Of the 48 affected structures, only 6 will require relocation
and  resettlement  of  the  households.  These  households  will  be  accommodated  in  the  same
village if possible. It is estimated that only two of the masonry structures will require relocation
away  from  their  existing  sites.  In  these  cases,  alternative  alignments  are  available  that  could
avoid relocation. As a result of the resettlement action plan, none of the affected households will
permanently  lose  either  agricultural  landholding  or  income  generation  sources.  A  summary  of
the land requirements by project component and the associated houses and structures affected
is shown in Table A9.1. Given that no encroachers or squatters are affected by the Project, and
that  many  of  the  affected  people  are  living  on  roadsides  where  access  is  easier,  the  affected
people are in general relatively well off.

1.
Under the Land Law (Article 43), persons entitled to use land have these rights: (i) keep
the  land  for  a  specific  purpose,  (ii)  use  the  land  in  accordance  with  the  State’s  management
plans, (iii) enjoy usufruct from the land, (iv) transfer the right of land use, and (v) bequeath the
right  of  land  use.  Article  63  states  that  the  right  of  land  use  will  terminate  either  through
voluntary  relinquishment  of  the  land  or  with  State  retrieval  of  the  land  for  public  purposes.
Compensation is treated in Articles 67-71, which require each village, province, municipality, or
special zone to keep 5 percent of its total land area in reserve for compensating requisitioned
land. However, most urban villages of Vientiane do not retain such a provision, and relocations
within  the  same  village  may  not  always  be  possible.  The  Road  Law  (1999)  sets  out  the  road
limits, including the right-of-way, for different classes of roads. By that law, people with land use
rights  will  be  compensated  if  the  land  is  expropriated  for  road  construction.  The  same  can  be
inferred as being applicable to those whose land is expropriated for drainage and other public
infrastructure.

POVERTY AND SOCIAL ISSUES AND STRATEGY1

A. 

Socioeconomic Profile of Urban Vientiane

1.

Socioeconomic Context

1.
The  Vientiane  urban  area  covers  100  villages  in  four  districts  for  which  the  Vientiane
Urban Development Administration Authority (VUDAA) is responsible. The current population is
estimated at 162,000 growing at the rate of 1.2 per annum over the past five years. The greater
Vientiane  urban  area,  within  the  boundaries  of  the  master  plan  cover  189  villages,  with  a
population  of  325,000,  growing  at  3.3  per  annum.  The  1997  Vientiane  Social  Survey  Project
indicates that about half the current population were born in the Vientiane urban area, and that
the bulk of rural-urban migration took place between 1975 and 1990. No official statistics exist
on recent migration trends, but anecdotal evidence suggests that there is a growing number of
migrant workers employed by the industry, especially textiles, although the scale is still limited.

The  ethnicity  composition  for  Vientiane  Prefecture  in  the  1995  Census  is  92.6  percent
2.
Lao  Loum  (lowland  Lao)  and  7.4  percent  various  ethnic  minority  groups.  However,  this
information  grossly  understates  the  ethnic  or  even  nationality  diversity  within  each  village  of
urban  Vientiane.  For  example,  Ban  Nong  Chan,  one  of  the  villages  selected  for  the  Project’s
participatory poverty assessment, had Lao (65 percent), Vietnamese (23 percent), and Chinese
and  others  (12  percent).  Ten  percent  of  the  population  was  unregistered  immigrants.  The
participatory  poverty  assessment  identified  that  ethnic  minorities  are  often  found  among  the
poorest and tenants without legal land titles.

3.
The Government sector, commerce, and trade employ more than 50 percent of the labor
force in urban districts, but 18 percent of the households still depend on farming as their primary
income source. The urban-rural mixture is apparent from the current land use pattern in which
agricultural  and  residential/commercial  land  plots  exist  side  by  side.  Many  of  the  households
have  more  than  one  income  source,  and  48  percent  depend  on  remittances  from  relatives
residing outside the country. Educational attainment is low – about 32 percent of the population
never  went  beyond  primary  school  –  and  that  of  women  is  much  lower;  about  45  percent  of
mothers  stopped  at  primary  level,  compared  with  28  percent  of  fathers.  Health  facilities  need
further upgrading. Water- and feces-borne diseases are highly prevalent, especially among the
poor, whose access to health services is limited.

2.

4.

development  index,  reflecting  its  low  performance  in  the  human  development  sector.  LECS  II
also estimates poverty incidence in urban Vientiane at 17 percent. This is close to the poverty
incidence  of  18  percent  identified  through  the  participatory  poverty  assessment  (based  on  the
information  collected  through  village  chiefs)  using  the  income  of  KN150,000  per  capita  per

to the poorest group with an income of less than KN60,000 per capita per month.

5.
Unlike  other  cities  in  the  region,  where  the  poor  reside  in  well-defined  slum  areas,  the
poor  in  the  Vientiane  urban  are  literally  hidden  in  pockets  throughout  the  city.  Urban  village
settlements are highly heterogeneous; the poor households are often found adjacent to higher-
income settlements. The vast majority of the poor live on low-lying wetland areas, flooded most
of  the  year.  These  areas  are  acutely  underserviced,  and  the  links  from  access  roads  to  the
dwellings are via difficult routes.

6.
Due  to  the  complex  nature  of  urban  poverty,  there  is  no  single  definition  of  the  poor,
However, the vulnerable groups, which are often the poor, include the physically and mentally
disabled,  drug  users/alcoholics,  elderly  people  living  alone,  the  homeless  and  street  children,
infrequent  beggars,  female  headed  households,  illegal  immigrants,  dropouts  and  unemployed
youth, large families with low income, and ethnic minorities. The poor can be categorized into
tuk ti sut  (the  poorest)  who  are  destitute,  tuk pang kang  (medium  poor)  usually  employed  in
irregular low-paying jobs, and tuk thammada (simple poor) who may have a house and land but
are very susceptible to slipping into a more vulnerable way of life.

7.
Poverty reduction is the Government's key development strategy. In the Seventh Round
Table  Meeting  in  November  2000,  the  Government  reconfirmed  its  commitment  to  eradicate
poverty  and  to  move  out  of  the  ranks  of  least  developed  countries  by  2020.  In  Vientiane
Prefecture, the governor issued a five-year plan to eradicate poverty by 2005. The participatory
poverty  assessment  noted,  however,  that  to  date  there  has  been  no  targeted  urban  poverty
reduction  programs,  although  emergency  assistance  during  fire  and  flood,  assistance  to  the
disabled and orphans, and access to metered electricity have been provided by the Ministry of
Social Welfare. There is also a system in urban Vientiane that the village authority enable the
poorest to receive some form of state assistance (e.g., rice provision) in case of emergencies or
other  external  shocks.  Other  formal  assistance  includes  a  village-based  revolving  drug  fund,
free treatment for registered destitute at district hospitals, subsidized education and vocational
courses,  and  an  orphan  center.  Financial  services  for  the  poor  are  currently  limited  to  the
savings and credit program funded by the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF),
and covering thus far 30 villages in Chanthabouly District. The program has been successfully
providing saving and credit services to 1,684 individuals since 1995 at a close to 100 percent
repayment rate.

Nonetheless,  formal  programs  do  not  reach  all  poor.  Informal  coping  mechanisms
8.
reported  by  the  poor  include  (i)  informal  support  system,  e.g.,  obtaining  food  or  borrowing
money  from  neighbors;  (ii)  engaging  in  survival  activities,  e.g.,  begging,  collecting  vegetables
and catching fish from swamps, and selling assets; (iii) engaging in illegal activities, e.g., drug
dealing, stealing, prostitution; and (iv) reducing consumption and costs of living, e.g., eating less
and not buying drinking water.

B.

Constraints on the Urban Poor

1.

Physical Exclusion

The  problem-ranking  exercise  of  the  participatory  poverty  assessment  found  that  the
9.
urban  poor  in  Vientiane  have  strong  and  urgent  need  for  improved  urban  infrastructure  and
services.  It  also  highlighted  the  strong  linkage  between  poor  infrastructure  conditions  and  the
ability  to  engage  in  subsistence  economic  activities  near  the  house.  The  service  problems
though  varied  across  villages  include  in  order  of  priority  (i)  constant  flooding,  (ii)  inadequate

 60

Appendix 10, page 3

access  paths  and  roads,  (iii)  poor  sanitation  facilities  and  sewerage,  (iv)  uncollected  rubbish,
and (v) sharing water and electricity supply.  All these problems are closely linked.

10.
Flooding is felt at almost all times of the year, as the poor tend to live in low-lying land. 
The situation was exacerbated recently with the construction of multistory concrete houses by
the better-off, which allow the run off from these houses into the adjacent lower, poorer areas
pushing  the  poor  back  onto  lower  and  more  marginal  land.  Polluted  water  flows  create  poor
environmental  conditions  and  waterborne  skin  and  foot  diseases.  Lack  of  space  outside  the
dwelling for daily activities hinders subsistence economic activities, such as growing vegetables
or raising livestock.

11.
Access paths are impossible or difficult to use because of constant flooding. During the
monsoon  season,  most  of  the  poor  access  their  dwellings  along  narrow  timber  planks,
balancing  on  dirty  floodwater.  The  elderly  and  disabled  cannot  go  out  of  their  houses,  which
worsens their vulnerability and marginalization. Even in higher areas, access may be limited by
the  narrow  width  of  the  paths  between  houses  and  the  unplanned  and  haphazard  settlement
pattern.  This  makes  the  service  delivery  difficult,  such  as  access  by  vacuum  tankers,  water
delivery  trucks,  emergency  services,  and  rubbish  collection  vehicles,  and  routing  of  water
supply pipes.

The  poor  do  not  have  access  to  a  typical  range  of  sanitation  options  available  to  low-
12.
income  households  in  many  other  countries.  The  most  common  system  is  to  dump  human
waste  into  floodwaters  or,  at  best,  in  corroded  oil  drums  thus  allowing  effluent  to  run  into  the
floodwaters. Most household sanitation facilities are without secure enclosure; this is especially
a problem for women.   

13.
There  is  almost  no  household  or  community  management  of  solid  waste  in  the  low-
income areas.  A large number of households throw their waste beside or under their dwellings
or dump it in the swamp or collection areas from which it is not always collected. This creates
unhygienic  conditions  with  flies,  and  rotting  waste  with  its  putrid  smells,  further  contaminating
the floodwaters.

Most households, except the poorest, have some level of access to piped water supply
14.
from Nam Papa Lao. The informal arrangement whereby the connected households sell water
to  the  unconnected  ones  at  a  fee  of  about  KN5,000-15,000  per  month  is  widespread.  Water
collected through flexible hoses is stored in drums for long periods creating a breeding ground
for  malarial  mosquitoes.  However,  apart  from  the  poorest,  most  poor  buy  bottled  water  for
drinking.  Electricity  coverage  is  also  high  at  about  90  percent.  The  same  informal  sharing
arrangement  as  with  water  exists  for  electricity;  the  proportions  of  metered  electricity  and
sharing are about 50:50. The poor allocate about 5 percent of their income to electricity. 

2.

Social Exclusion

15.
One  key  manifestation  of  the  social  exclusion  of  the  poor  is  the  formal  land  titling
process.  The  Land  Titling  Project,  financed  by  the  World  Bank  and  Australian  Agency  for
International  Development,  is  in  the  process  of  surveying,  assigning,  and  registering  titles
throughout Vientiane Prefecture and other towns. As of January 2001, 57 villages in Vientiane
urban  area  have  completed  the  process,  10  villages  have  started,  and  33  villages  have  not
started. Around 13,000 of about 49,000 titles have been issued. The notable lack of formal land
use  rights  among  most  of  the  poor  households  suggests  that  the  land  titling  initiative  is
benefiting  better-off  groups,  e.g.,  government  officials  and  war  veterans,  disproportionately.

recognized deserving of their land use rights. 

16.
Poverty and lack of land use rights are closely linked.  Fear of eviction was ranked one

water and electricity supplies. Under these circumstances, the poor have little incentive to invest
in maintaining and upgrading their housing and urban services.

1.

Physical Environment

In general, the project sites can be classified as urban or semi-urban. They are all within the
5.
urban  core  areas,  which  are  generally  characterized  by  low-  or  medium-rise  development,
containing  significant  areas  of  poor-quality  infrastructure  and  housing,  interspersed  with  small
areas of open wasteland, urban agriculture and wetland. The built-up environment of Vientiane is
highly  heterogeneous,  with  most  villages  exhibiting  a  mixture  of  high-,  medium-  and  low-  density
housing  within  an  area  of  a  few  hectares.  Many  sites  are  low-lying  and  are  subject  to  frequent

 flooding during the monsoon season. The growth and development of many of the urban areas are
unplanned.  While  much  of  the  primary  road  and  drainage  network  is  recently  constructed,  and
generally in good condition, local roads are frequently narrow (seldom more than 4 - 5 meters [m]
wide) and vary in quality of construction and maintenance.

6.
Vientiane  lies  on  the  left  bank  of  the  Mekong  River,  and  is  part  of  the  alluvial  plain  that
constitutes  most  of  Vientiane  Prefecture.  The  soils  are  in  general  clay  loam  to  a  depth  of  1  m,
below which lies a gravel clay loam to a depth of about 7 m. Below this lies a sandy gravel and silt
layer. Most of the urban core area is flat with an elevation of 168 to 170m above ordinance datum,
although  a  slight  ridge  in  the  east  rises  a  few  meters  to  a  height  of  180  m.  Wetland  areas  lie  at
elevations  between  167  and  168  m  above  ordinance  datum.  The  water  table  fluctuates  with  the
season, but is highest at 168m. The urban area is protected from inundation during Mekong flood
events by a bund 175 m high. Vientiane has a tropical climate with average annual temperatures
ranging  from  a  low  of  18°C  during  December-February,  to  31-33°C  during  March-May.  The
average  annual  precipitation  is  between  1,100  and  2,300  millimeters  a  year,  with  more  than  85
percent of the rain falling during the monsoon season in May-September.

2.

Biological Environment

7.
While  the  Lao  People's  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  has  a  rich  and  diverse  range  of
tropical flora and fauna, those in the urban and semi-urban areas covered by the Project are typical
of  flora  and  fauna  in  the  urban  environment.  The  most  notable  flora  are  the  mature  indigenous
hardwood  trees  lining  major  thoroughfares.  Sadly,  only  a  few  of  these  remain.  Other  trees  are
mostly ornamental and shade trees planted along roadsides and in gardens. There is some urban
agriculture–largely  irrigated  and  unirrigated  rice  land.  The  fauna  in  the  urban  area  are  primarily
grazing animals such as sheep and goats, domestic animals such as chickens, dogs and ducks,
and  small  reptiles–the  common  gecko  and  lizards.  Also  common  are  pests–rodents,  stray  cats,
and insects that typically thrive on wastes in urban environment.

3.

Sociocultural Environment

8.
For a capital city, the population density of Vientiane is low at about 55 persons per hectare
in  the  urban  core  area.  Furthermore,  the  population  growth  rate  in  Vientiane  urban  area  is  not
high—averaging about 1.2 percent per annum between 1995 and 2000. The literacy rate is high—
over  95  percent.  Of  the  numerous  ethnic  groups  in  Vientiane,  almost  all  are  Lao;  only  about  1
percent of the population are reported to be non-Lao.1 About half of the existing urban population
moved to Vientiane after 1975, most in the first five years.

Under  the  Law,  VUDAA  is  to  establish  an  environmental  management  and  monitoring  unit  in
cooperation with the Science, Technology, and Environment Agency. The duties of this unit include
(i) preparing and implementing plans for environmental protection of the Vientiane urban area; (ii)
monitoring  and  controlling  the  implementation  of  environmental  legislative  instruments;  (iii)
conducting research and identifying methods for environmental protection and restoration; and (iv)
collecting,  analyzing,  and  disseminating  information  on  the  environment  and  related  issues.  The
unit  responsible  for  these  activities  within  VUDAA  is  the  Sanitation  and  Environment  Division,
which is also responsible for solid waste collection and disposal, septic tank emptying, and street
cleaning.  While  the  existing  staff  are  adequate  in  number  to  perform  this  mandate,  they  lack  the
necessary  skills.  The  capacity  building  component  of  the  Project  will  provide  training  both  in  the
management of environmental services and in monitoring environmental conditions in the broader
sense.

F. 

Findings and Recommendations

24.
The  proposed  Project  aims  to  improve  environment  in  the  Vientiane  urban  area,  and  will
contribute significantly to improved living conditions and well-being of the urban poor. The risk to
the urban population, particularly the urban poor, of incurring infectious diseases through exposure
to contaminated surface water will be low. In addition, the health risk and public nuisance caused
by mosquitoes and flies will be reduced as a result of the reduction in suitable breeding areas for
infectious disease vectors. The air quality and public safety will be enhanced by the improved road
network and access to village areas.

25.
On the basis of this initial evaluation, the Project is unlikely to result in any direct adverse
environmental impacts. The identified adverse effects should be readily addressed through proper
engineering design and incorporation of the identified mitigation measures. Adverse impacts relate
almost  entirely  to  the  construction  phase,  and  particular  attention  will  be  paid  to  ensuring  that
contractors comply with good engineering practice and avoid creating unnecessary inconvenience
to  the  public.  Assuming  that  the  construction  process  is  well-managed,  the  short-term  negative
impacts of the Project will be far outweighed by the major positive impacts of an improved urban
environment.

Traffic Management and Road Safety

a. 

Public Lighting

1.
Very few of the 279 km of primary, secondary, and tertiary roads in the Vientiane urban area
are adequately lit at night. It is proposed that street lighting be installed along 18 kilometers of the 102
km  of  primary  and  secondary  road  in  the  urban  area,  at  a  base  cost  of  $0.84  million.  Allowing  for
capital and O&M costs and the opportunity cost of capital, the total annual cost of public lighting will
be  equivalent  to  $150,000  per  year.  Street  lighting  is  a  public  good  with  substantial  benefits  for  the
community,  including  (i)  a  decline  in  the  number  and  severity  of  road  vehicle  accidents,  especially
those  involving  pedestrians;  (ii)  reduced  travel  time  and  vehicle  operating  costs  for  motorists;  (iii)
fewer  accidents,  greater  convenience,  and  enhanced  personal  security  of  pedestrians  using
footpaths; and (iv) increased opportunity for social and business activity.

Available  data  is  insufficient  for  an  economic  evaluation  of  the  proposed  street  lighting
2.
program.  However,  the  benefits  of  street  lighting  and  its  current  limited  presence  mean  that  the
marginal benefit to be gained from its provision is greater than would be the case were the project to
involve extension of a more extensive current system. The benefit of the street lighting program will
be  maximized  by  determining  the  locations  where  lights  are  to  be  installed  during  project
implementation,  using  a  multicriteria  assessment  of  all  primary  and  secondary  roads  that  takes
account  of  (i) the quantity of traffic  using each road, (ii) the number of  traffic accidents, and (iii)  the
quality of footpaths on the roads.

3.
The  Vientiane  Urban  Development  and  Administration  Authority  (VUDAA)  is  to  collect  a
surcharge on electricity accounts to meet the cost of public lighting. The surcharge is currently set at
KN1,000 per electricity meter per month, which is 0.3 percent of the 25th percentile household income.
Practices such as sharing of electricity between several poor households or poor households drawing
on  power  from  a  better-off  neighbor  will  temper  the  effect  of  the  surcharge  on  the  poor.  Financial
forecasts  for  VUDAA  has  made  allowances  for  the  cost  of  maintaining  and  operating  the  public
lighting, and for increases in the rate of the electricity surcharge to cover the cost of public lighting.

b. 

Traffic Signals, Signage, and Safety Awareness

4.
The traffic management strategy, which will involve installation of traffic signals, traffic signs,
and  road  marking,  and  improved  traffic  safety  awareness,  responds  to  traffic  growth,  poor  traffic
management,  and  deteriorating  road  safety  in  Vientiane.  The  benefits  of  the  strategy  will  be  (i)
reduced  number  and  severity  of  road  accidents,  (ii)  reduced  vehicle  operating  costs  resulting  from
improved  traffic  flow,  and  (iii)  increased  capacity  of  the  road  system.  The  accident  rate  in  Vientiane
has been rising, with the number of fatalities growing from an average annual rate of 4.8 per 10,000
vehicles in 1980-1984 to 8.0, 11.8, and 12.5 in subsequent five-year periods (and 10.2 in 1999). The
number  of  accidents  resulting  in  injuries  has  risen  at  a  faster  rate.  Over  the  decade  to  1999,  the
number of deaths and fatalities rose at 120 percent of the rate of growth in the number of registered
vehicles.  The  recent  average  death  rate  of  12.5  per  10,000  vehicles  in  Vientiane  is  high  compared
with that in other countries (in 1997 national road deaths per 10,000 vehicles were 11.8 in Indonesia,
8.5 in Thailand, 2.3 in Australia, and 1.6 in Japan, with death rates in urban areas typically about a
quarter  lower  than  these  national  rates).  Traffic  accidents  in  Vientiane  are  concentrated  in  certain
areas (for  example,  33 of the 106 deaths in 1999   occurred   at   13  intersections),  which should be
the focus of traffic management strategy. During project implementation, the benefits of the strategy
will be maximized by assessing the entire road network and prioritizing the location of measures on
the basis of the quantity of traffic and the number of accidents.
